title: Sound card & ALSA support
body: Consider adding support for sound cards & ALSA to WSL?

comments.body: Is the source code available to the Windows 9p server which provides WSL2 access to things like /mnt/c/ from the guest?

Point of order please... The request is for sound support (command line) which has nothing to do with X/GUI desktops, apps, and tools. After a three year wait surely the future is now here and hopefully it is one that believes in equal access at Microsoft?
For the blind: My middle fingers are in the air on your behalf... For the sighted: You can't see me doing it anyway :p
"Yes, I appreciate that, but what developer scenario does the lack of PulsAudio hinder?"

Please please please! This would open up so much, and I wish it was a much higher priority. I know devs think of this as a feature for other devs, but it is incredibly useful for highly technical users as well. Not having sound, I mean can you imagine windows itself without sound? Please give us at least this access.
I'm a blind developer, and I would use Festival TS syste, that works under linux. This software connects with alsa, and, however I installe dpulseaudio server, it doesn't work.
I hope the workaround works
Here there is a workaround, though I have not tested it yet:
Hello Admin, can you suggest us any workaround ? Look : 270 votes ! May be the time to change a little your priorities...
Useful for alerting via audio when long-running scripts are completed.
For me it would also be essential to be able to use the Ubuntu subsystem with pyaudio, sound support.
this gets my upvote

I know thath GUI isn't offically suppoted. so, I do not need GUI.
But I hope develop google-assistant client on WSL. its needs ALSA support, not GUI.

I think the point made is that it's inappropriate to label this feature, which is used for accessibility purposes as "not currently a high priority" -- while several developers are talking about 'utility', the accessibility efforts of the greater MS company are clearly misaligned in this case.

What!? I keep getting so excited (for years now) and then being utterly disappointed. How is audio not nailed down? Is it that hard to pipe something like a PCM stream from what would otherwise go to the audio hardware and then catch that on Windows and play it? I know that's WAY oversimplified, but I've accomplished much more with WAY less, even with video.

It has always been clear that GUI isn't officially supported though hopefully that will change when the #1 Uservoice flips (this isn't it). The custom ppa hasn't worked in awhile since it's not being maintained anymore (so newer pulse audio packages can't be fixed). Pulse Audio itself technically is good in Skip-Ahead builds, leaving just the API driver support. This is another thing I hope we can see this fall.

Not having command-line sound support in WSL is a fundamental & extremely frustrating omission. I hoped this would be resolved in the April update but it hasn't. Please can you clarify what you mean when you say "several scenarios"; does this include WSL accessibility issues? If so, why is this not "a high priority for us?"
I want to use this https://mycroft.ai/get-started/ and be able to talk to it and be able to hear it. It installs fine and runs fine other wise. I can type to it and it works great.
"I want to point out that we have very clear that"
There is a custom ppa created by @therealkenc hosted on Launchpad you can add to your repositories. This is the workaround until we can access the hardware via Linux drivers.
